front.note: Confidential: not for distribution. Submitted to IOP Publishing for peer review

docTitle.titlePart:
Strangeness in High Multiplicity Proton-Proton
Collisions in the ALICE Experiment

byline.affiliation: School of Physics and Astronomy, University of Birmingham,

front.div:
Abstract. The ALICE experiment at CERN is primarily focused on quark-gluon
plasma production in heavy ion (Pb-Pb) collisions. In addition, high multiplicity
events from the LHC pp programme will provide an interesting field of study. As with
A-A collisions, high multiplicity could suggest high underlying energy density of the
system, possibly exceeding that required for deconfinement. Bjorken first suggested
that deconfinement might occur in pp collisions, and evidence for this was sought by
the E-735 experiment at Fermilab but no clear signature was seen. The LHC will offer
new possibilities for examining this idea owing to the much greater multiplicity reach
available at higher energy. The ALICE experiment has powerful triggering tools and
particle identification (PID), which place it in a strong position to analyse these events
and to measure the observable signatures of deconfinement that may arise. Signatures
particularly related to strangeness production will be outlined and the capabilities for
such studies at ALICE will be discussed.
front.keywords:
Keywords: high multiplicity, deconfinement, strangeness, phi resonance, proton
collisions, heavy ion, quark-gluon plasma, ALICE
